review.title: Control Matching via Discharge Code Sequences
review.abstract: In this paper, we consider the patient similarity matching problem over a cancer cohort of more than 220,000 patients. Our approach first leverages on Word2Vec framework to embed ICD codes into vector-valued representation. We then propose a sequential algorithm for case-control matching on this representation space of diagnosis codes. The novel practice of applying the sequential matching on the vector representation lifted the matching accuracy measured through multiple clinical outcomes. We reported the results on a large-scale dataset to demonstrate the effectiveness of our method. For such a large dataset where most clinical information has been codified, the new method is particularly relevant.

metadata.title: Control Matching via Discharge Code Sequences

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The basic idea is that a patient (called a case) is typically paired with a clinically similar patient (called a control) in terms of the ICD code sequence. To determine the similarity of two ICD code sequences, one can compare their primary diagnosis (i.e., their first ICD code) [1, 6] or calculate their hamming distance [5]. A major difficulty in comparing ICD code sequences is variation in coding, i.e., different ICD codes can be used to record the same disease. For example, both ICD codes I20.0 and R57.0 are related to the "heart problem." Another difficulty is the sequential meaning in the code sequences that most existing approaches fail to establish the clinical relationship between syntactically different ICD codes or the relative position of ICD within a similar space.

sections.heading: 2.1 Phase 1: Learning ICD code vectors
sections.text: WVM uses Word2Vec (Skip-gram model [7]) to learn ICD code vectors that can capture the latent relationships between ICD codes. This idea was also used in [3, 2]. Local context is defined as ICD codes that appear in the same episode (recording) with a window size of 5. These ICD code vectors are then used in a sequential matching algorithm in phase 2.

sections.heading: 2.2 Phase 2: Building a matching algorithm
sections.text: The inputs of the sequential matching (SM) algorithm are a group of cases (case group) and a group of controls (control group). We will describe how we select case group and control group in Section 3.2. SM has three main steps. Step 1: For a given case tc (i) it finds a validation group consisting of controls that have the same sex and age group as tc (i). sections.heading: 3 Experiments

sections.heading: 3.1 Data
sections.text: The data set is a cancer cohort of more than 220,000 patients (58.2% men, mean age 71) collected from a national cancer registry of 21 hospitals in Australia between 1997 and 2012. The data sets include demographic data and diagnoses indicated by ICD-10 codes. There is no information on laboratories, procedures or medicines. A subset of data for control comparison was selected as follows: 1) We removed ICD codes that occurred less than 30 times; 2) We retained only those admissions that had at least one ICD code; and 3) We removed admissions that occurred after 2008 / 12 / 31. The remaining data set contains 1,810,967 admissions (216,844 individual patients).

sections.heading: 3.2 Construction of case group and control group
sections.text: First, we randomly selected a combination of a hospital H and an admission year Y from the data set. Then, we selected the admission that had the same hospital and admission year as H and Y. Note that each admission is related to a different patient. This admission is called HY. Finally, we created the case group by selecting 200 images from HY in a random sample. The remaining images in HY were used to form the control group. Admission to the control group is associated with patients who are different from those in the case group.

sections.heading: 3.3 Performance evaluation
sections.text: To make a fair comparison, all baselines were performed after step 1 was performed in the SM (i.e. after we received a validation group), and each time we received 200 cases and 200 matching controls, measuring the consistency of the two cohorts with the two clinical outcomes.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: We have introduced WVM, a clinical outcome-based case-control matching method that utilizes both the representative similarity between the ICD-10 codes and the sequential structure of the coding at each recording. Evaluating two measures of similarity based on clinical outcomes, namely reuptake accuracy and cancer mortality incidence rate errors, proves that WVM is a more effective solution to match patient similarity in a large cancer cohort. In practice, this means that WVM can identify a control cohort that better matches the case cohort, minimizing potential distortion between the two cohorts, enabling more effective experiments or quasi-experiments with a large coded dataset similar to ours.
